6.text:
Well good afternoon and thank
you,

8.text:
President Werner, for your kind
introduction,

10.text:
as well as your flexibility in
rescheduling this event,

14.text:
given the weather challenges of
the week.

18.text:
and I appreciate your interest
in Penn State and higher
education.

22.text:
A special welcome to all of the
Penn Staters here,

26.text:
along with those of you covering
educational issues.

30.text:
We need your continued
engagement. Again, thank you for
joining us.

34.text:
and thank you for bringing along
the Penn State cookies.

38.text:
According to Google News, there
are over 45,000 stories about
Penn State and Sandusky.

46.text:
You've written them. You've read
them.

49.text:
And I imagine that most of you
have formed an opinion

53.text:
about Penn State and our actions
over the last year.

57.text:
But beyond the headlines,
there's another reality...one
that exists

63.text:
for Penn State's 96,000
students, 44,000 full- and
part-time faculty and staff,

69.text:
and over 550,000 living alumni.
It's a world of teaching,
research and service.

77.text:
It's a world with an $800
million research program,
hundreds of degrees offered,

83.text:
24 campuses, 
an online World Campus, an
academic health center,

88.text:
a law school, and 157 years of
tradition.

93.text:
It's also a world that has
continued to face ongoing
controversy

96.text:
surrounding Jerry Sandusky, our
Board of Trustees, current and
former administrators, and me.

104.text:
The legal process continues to
unfold as evidenced by the
Attorney General's further charges leveled yesterday.

112.text:
Today, I want to tell you
something about my world—with
the realities of running an institution

117.text:
the size and scope of Penn
State, while dealing with widely
divergent perceptions.

124.text:
I want to share the many
wonderful activities and
accomplishments of our students,

128.text:
faculty and staff over this
agonizing year. By any
reasonable definition, they are newsworthy stories.

138.text:
But I understand that you may
not be willing to listen to them

141.text:
until we show you how this year
has changed us.

145.text:
What have we learned about
ourselves?

148.text:
And what are we trying to do
with that knowledge?

151.text:
I will speak candidly about how
the last year has affected Penn
State,

156.text:
and how the impact has gone
beyond Central Pennsylvania to
shape policies at colleges and universities across the nation.

164.text:
Then I'll share our strategies
for the year ahead.

168.text:
To begin, let me take you back
to last year when Penn State
received the repugnant news

174.text:
that a former assistant coach
had molested young boys, in some
instances on our campus.

181.text:
Immediately, as they did with
all of you, our thoughts turned
to the victims of these horrific crimes.

188.text:
And, in the days that followed,
we saw the removal of the senior
leaders of our university and athletic program,

196.text:
including the popular president
and iconic football coach.

200.text:
At the time, I was serving as
the executive vice president and
provost,

205.text:
a position I have often called
the best job in higher
education.

210.text:
My retirement was within my
sights.

213.text:
When the Board of Trustees asked
me to serve as president, I
accepted,

218.text:
knowing full well that the
months ahead would explore
uncharted territory for our university.

224.text:
Many times I've been asked, "Why
did you say yes?!"

231.text:
I've devoted 35 years of my
professional life to Penn State.

235.text:
My children attended Penn State.
I believe deeply in our mission
and our ability to contribute to the greater good.

243.text:
I knew I needed to step up and
serve.

246.text:
I also knew that Penn State is a
great university.  A great
university that will endure as it has always endured,

254.text:
will recover, and will continue
to advance teaching, research
and service.

261.text:
In those early weeks, I heard
from Penn State's many
constituents

265.text:
-- through more than 5,000
emails and letters, and hundreds
of phone calls and personal contacts.

273.text:
People were shocked, upset,
concerned, disappointed and yet
supportive of the university.

282.text:
Meanwhile, as the story played
out in the media, in alumni
circles, and in every corner of our campuses,

289.text:
voices that had remained silent
for many years began to speak
up. Victims of child abuse wrote to my office.

297.text:
These individuals were abused by
family members and
acquaintances;  indeed only 10% of sexual abuse is perpetrated by a stranger.

308.text:
They were part of the chilling
estimates -- one in five girls
and one in ten boys are sexually abused by the age of 18.

315.text:
The majority of those victims
will never tell anyone -- even
if they've been asked.

322.text:
The letters were powerful,
expressing bottled up pain,
shame and struggles these individuals have lived with over many years.

331.text:
For some, this was the first
time they had shared their
story.

336.text:
Another has written regularly
and met with some of my top
administrators to collaborate on ways to help victims of child sexual abuse.

345.text:
I found these stories to be
heartbreaking, but I also found
hope in them.

350.text:
Those who wrote were entrusting
their stories to us, and more
importantly,

355.text:
they were looking to us to help
tackle what is an insidious,
hidden and epidemic issue.

362.text:
They still believed in our
capabilities, even as we
wrestled with our own despair about what had happened.

369.text:
Their issue became our issue,
and we resolved to move forward
by using all that is right about Penn State

376.text:
to take on this nationwide
problem of child abuse.

380.text:
And we resolved to do it by
doing what we do best, that is
teaching, research and service.

388.text:
Beyond that, we have something
even more powerful --our student
body.

401.text:
they were moving forward with
unity and a constructive energy
that's been inspiring to all of us.

407.text:
Here are just two quick
examples:

410.text:
By the end of the first week,
student leaders had organized a
candlelight vigil on the Old Main lawn

415.text:
to show support for the victims
of child sexual abuse.

420.text:
Thousands of Penn State students
and community members joined
together in the stillness of a cold,

425.text:
dark night to remind others
that—at the core of the issue we
faced—were children who had been gravely harmed.

433.text:
The following week, graduate
students Laura March and Stuart
Shapiro helped mobilize the Penn State community

442.text:
with the goal of raising
awareness and funds for
combating child abuse.

448.text:
Working with a tight
timeline―right before the
Nittany Lions were to play their first football game in the aftermath of this tragedy

455.text:
Laura and Stuart organized the
first annual Blue Out, to
represent the color of ribbons worn in support of child abuse awareness.

465.text:
This year was the second annual
"Blue Out."

468.text:
Together, they raised $126,000
for Prevent Child Abuse
Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Coalition Against Rape.

478.text:
Laura and Stuart, please stand
for a moment so we can recognize
you.

494.text:
Penn State alumni have also
shown their support, raising
nearly $550,000 for RAINN,

500.text:
the country's largest
anti-sexual violence
organization.

504.text:
Those are just a few examples of
many acts -- large and
small—that were organized and carried out by Penn Staters.

513.text:
What's more, students continue
to respond to the crisis,

516.text:
while still doing the things
Penn State students have always
loved to do: study and learn,

523.text:
participate in clubs and
activities, make friends, look
forward to the future,

529.text:
and cheer on 800-plus
student-athletes in 31 varsity
sports, including a football team, I might add,

536.text:
whose performance on and off the
field has made us proud.

541.text:
As administrators, we tried to
balance the need to move ahead
with the need to reflect on, and correct,

548.text:
the underlying issues that
brought us to the crisis in the
first place.

552.text:
The trustees began by asking
former FBI director Louis Freeh
to lead an independent investigation,

560.text:
which yielded 119
recommendations on how to
enhance our internal policies and practices.

567.text:
We've already implemented more
than one-third of these
recommendations,

571.text:
and many more are nearing
completion.  We remain committed
to this progress

576.text:
because we believe it's making
us a better, stronger
university.

581.text:
And we're committed to the fight
against child abuse.

584.text:
Central to this effort is the
newly established Center for the
Protection of Children

590.text:
based at the Penn State Hershey
Children's Hospital, and our
ongoing partnership with the Pennsylvania Coalition Against Rape.

597.text:
Earlier this week we completed
the first Penn State National
Conference on Child Sexual Abuse.

604.text:
This forum brought together
leaders and experts from law
enforcement, pediatric medicine, prevention research, and education.

614.text:
We formed the Penn State Network
for Child Protection and
Well-Being,

618.text:
comprised of 35 faculty members
with interdisciplinary
expertise.

624.text:
The aim is to accelerate the
pace of discovery by linking
research and practice,

629.text:
and to build the Network with
additional researchers,
practitioners and teachers.

635.text:
Dr. Susan McHale, Director of
the Social Science Research
Institute, and one of the co-organizers of the Network is here with us today.

643.text:
Susan, can you please stand and
be recognized? Thank you.

652.text:
We also made a pledge to educate
our university community about
ethics.

657.text:
It's one thing to know the
rules, regulations and policies;

661.text:
it's another thing to create a
culture where every employee
wants to do the right thing, the first time, every time.

668.text:
Through training and
awareness-building efforts,
we're trying to help people understand the how, when, where and why of reporting.

676.text:
I assure you that Penn State
takes this commitment very
seriously.

680.text:
That's not a glib promise. To
prove it, we have stepped up our
efforts in compliance.

686.text:
Like most universities, Penn
State has dozens of compliance
professionals.

692.text:
They're responsible for ensuring
research funds are appropriately
used; they monitor our NCAA compliance, our financial reporting,

705.text:
and they administer many more
regulations related to the
health, welfare and safety of those on our campuses, including our patients.

714.text:
What we discovered, however, is
that despite our staffing, there
were gaps in the system,

720.text:
and we lacked a central
compliance office where these
efforts can be coordinated.

725.text:
We have since hired the
university's first full-time
compliance coordinator to ensure Penn State's overall compliance with the Clery Act.

734.text:
With this new position, our goal
is to not only ensure that Penn
State meets the requirements set forth by federal law and the U.S. Department of Education,

744.text:
but to become a leader in campus
safety, security and compliance.

749.text:
Another example is the Athletics
Integrity Agreement between the
NCAA and Penn State,

755.text:
with oversight by Sen. George
Mitchell. This should help put
the question of athletic integrity to rest even as we implement changes.

765.text:
There is a great deal that is
right about athletics at Penn
State.

770.text:
Our student-athletes graduate
well above their peers
nationwide.

782.text:
the football team's rate is 91%.
This level of achievement spans
all sports teams,

790.text:
academic majors and ethnicity:
notably African-American
student-athletes earned a record 90% rate,

797.text:
which is 25 points higher than
the national average.

802.text:
Indeed, other universities are
closely watching Penn State's
actions, so they can strengthen their policies,

809.text:
mitigate risk at their
institutions, and make their
campuses safer.

814.text:
States from California to
Florida have introduced
legislation to make it clear

819.text:
that child abuse reporting is
not only a moral duty, it's the
law.

824.text:
This is tremendous progress:
laws strengthened, policies
tightened,

829.text:
governance revisited, and
institutions made safer. And our
work continues.

837.text:
That brings us to today -- on
the brink of the one-year
anniversary,

842.text:
civil lawsuits, perjury trials,
and we can expect more fallout
to come.

848.text:
Over the last year, we have
learned much about ourselves,
our many cultures, our values and our vision.

855.text:
We're still working through some
difficult issues, but the
question remains: Where do we go from here?

862.text:
The answer can be found by
returning to Penn State's core
mission: teaching, research and service.

869.text:
Our bottom line is delivering an
outstanding education to
students.

874.text:
Our students are our top
priority.  I repeat. Our
students are our top priority.

881.text: And they are doing great things.

884.text:
For example, this year our
journalism students captured the
national championship

889.text:
in the William Randolph Hearst
Foundation's Journalism Awards
Program.

899.text:
others are racing to get their
vehicle to the moon in the
Google Lunar X PRIZE Competition.

905.text:
Meteorology students won the
National Weather Forecasting
Challenge, and notably,

910.text:
this week more than 3,400 Penn
State meteorology alumni were
tracking Hurricane Sandy for the government, private industry, the military, media and education.

924.text:
In addition, this fall we
welcomed one of the largest and
most academically accomplished classes in our history

930.text:
after receiving a record 123,000
total applications for
admissions.

936.text:
These successes define who we
are and where we're going.

941.text:
We need to support those
students and faculty members,
because they depend on us.

946.text:
Our alumni and the people of the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
depend on us for educational opportunities,

952.text:
economic development, and
competitiveness. And our nation
depends on us for ground-breaking research and training

958.text:
for the next generation of
leaders, scientists, thinkers
and teachers.

964.text:
Allow me to put a few faces on
the Penn State community.

968.text:
Will Cat Powers and Will Martin
please stand?

971.text:
Cat and Will are student leaders
working to fight pediatric
cancer through service to THON,

977.text:
the largest student-run
philanthropy in the world. Since
1977, THON has raised more than $89 million for the Four Diamonds Fund

987.text:
at the Penn State Milton S.
Hershey Medical Center.

991.text:
We brought along DVDs of the
documentary "Why We Dance: The
Story of THON" for all of you.

997.text:
Please pick up a copy on the way
out -- it's an incredible story.

1010.text:
Will Dr. Cathy Bowen please
stand?

1013.text:
Cathy is a professor of
agricultural and extension
education consumer issues.

1019.text:
In addition to a full time
teaching and research agenda,
she runs a volunteer service to help income-eligible people get their taxes done for free.

1029.text:
Last year, the program completed
nearly 700 tax returns and saved
the elderly, working families and students at least $133,000.

1039.text:
The program's total economic
impact was nearly $1 million.
Thank you, Cathy.

1048.text:
Finally, I want to introduce Dr.
Sandeep Prahbu and Dr. Robert
Paulson, who are both professors in our College of Agricultural Sciences.

1058.text:
Their inspiring collaboration
discovered what could be a
promising treatment for leukemia.

1063.text:
In laboratory tests, the
compound they developed targeted
and killed leukemia stem cells, without relapse.

1071.text:
Their team, which includes
undergraduate as well as
graduate students, is now working to move this compound into clinical trials as soon as possible.

1086.text:
These are Penn Staters who are
leading us into the future.

1090.text:
They are the people I work for
every day.

1094.text:
They're the reason that I'm here
today. And they are just a few
of the Penn Staters

1098.text:
who will not allow anything to
stop them from changing our
world for the better.

1104.text:
With that in mind, I want to
spend a few minutes looking
ahead, because we're currently facing a crisis in higher education

1111.text:
that is perhaps the worst ever
in our nation's history: our
young people from middle-class

1116.text:
and working families--people
like Cat, Will, Laura and
Stuart--

1121.text:
who for generations have
depended on access to affordable
community colleges and state universities,

1128.text:
they're now at risk of losing
that access. Throughout the
nation, state governments are cutting back on the funding

1134.text:
that helps keep tuition
affordable, and the cuts
threaten the system of public higher education

1145.text:
that began when Abraham Lincoln
signed the Morrill Land-Grant
Act 150 years ago.

1151.text:
A report by the National Science
Board, released just last month,

1155.text:
found that state support for
public universities fell 20%
between 2002 and 2010, and this shortfall has put public research universities in peril.

1167.text:
The declining investment in
universities has made this a
lost decade for funding, and worse,

1174.text:
it has happened while
universities have increased
enrollment by 320,000 students nationally.

1181.text:
This has caused many to begin to
question the future of public
higher education, and the implications for society.

1189.text:
This is not a Chicken Little
warning, and as a university
president, I'm acutely aware that we need to adapt to today's economic realities.

1198.text:
To be sure, state legislatures
and governors have tough
choices:

1203.text:
their ability to provide
government services has
decreased while the public's need for them has increased.

1211.text:
And we know the difficulty of
asking already hard-pressed
Americans to pay higher taxes to subsidize public university tuition

1218.text:
to enable lower and middle
income families to afford to
send their children to college.

1225.text:
But we must address the current
reality that our nation's public
universities are charging tuitions

1230.text:
that even in-state students find
increasingly out of their reach.

1234.text:
Without a doubt, everyone in
leadership at public
universities can and must do a better job of reducing costs and improving education.

1244.text:
Further belt-tightening must
occur on university campuses
everywhere.

1249.text:
Every member of the university
community shares that
responsibility.

1254.text:
We at Penn State know this, and
we're turning over every stone
to find savings

1258.text:
and efficiencies while improving
learning outcomes.

1262.text:
This year, we had the lowest
tuition increase in 45 years.

1267.text:
We have trimmed budgets, cut
programs, and consolidated
functions.

1271.text:
But you can't do 21st century
science in labs leftover from
the days of Sputnik or before.

1279.text:
And as the CEO and psychologist
Shawn Achor has said,

1283.text:
"If we study what is merely
average, we will remain merely
average."

1289.text:
Our students and our nation
deserve better.

1292.text:
And we must do better if we
intend to compete in the global
economy.

1296.text:
Last year I traveled to China
and visited several
universities.

1300.text:
The national investment in these
universities, their research
facilities, and higher education is something to behold.

1308.text:
Over the last 30 years, China
has had a 58-fold increase in
spending

1313.text:
on education, health and social
investments.

1317.text:
According to a report from the
Center for American Progress, by
2030,

1322.text:
China will have more than 200
million college graduates, 
which is more than the entire U.S. workforce.

1330.text:
In five years India will be
producing five times as many
college graduates as the United States.

1336.text:
These are the facts that drive
the decisions we must make as we
position Penn State to succeed in the future.

1344.text:
Part of that strategic planning
will require getting out and
staying out in front of the information technology revolution,

1351.text:
which has been among the most
significant drivers of
educational change in the last 15 to 20 years.

1357.text:
It has also been like a runaway
train.

1361.text:
One response to the higher
education funding crisis has
been increased appeals,

1366.text:
especially from legislators and
business leaders, for higher
education to drastically increase online education.

1373.text:
The hope is that more students
will receive college degrees
faster and at less cost.

1379.text:
In fact, research shows that
done appropriately, the
application of  technologies can both improve learning outcomes AND decrease the costs of delivering that education.

1390.text:
But so far, big savings have
proven elusive.

1394.text:
Nonetheless, Massive Open Online
Courses are testing the market.

1399.text:
Dozens of universities,
including MIT, Harvard,
Princeton and Stanford,

1404.text:
now offer these classes,
prompting headlines like
"College may never be same." So stay tuned. It could be a wild ride.

1414.text:
Obviously, good ideas take time
and research to explore.

1418.text:
Penn State operates a World
Campus with nearly 12,000
students enrolled in dozens of fully online programs.

1426.text:
Our model has been honored by
the Sloan Consortium as the top
online program for 2012.

1435.text:
Finally, in the coming year, we
must prepare Penn State for the
next generation of leadership.

1442.text:
I announced that I will be
retiring by June 2014,

1446.text:
and the Board of Trustees is
about to begin the search for
the next president.

1451.text:
It's incumbent upon us to lay
the groundwork for my successor,
and we look forward to an invigorating process with many outstanding candidates.

1461.text:
Penn State continues to move
forward and embrace the
challenges.

1465.text:
Not only those that have come
from the events of the past
year,

1469.text:
but those that come from being
part of the higher education
landscape,

1473.text:
a large public land grant
research university, and yes, a
university that continues

1479.text:
to believe that great academics
and great athletics can not only
co-exist,

1484.text:
but can be mutually reinforcing
components of a university
education.

1490.text:
I hope you can better understand
why I'm proud to be the
president of our university.

1496.text:
It's because of our students,
faculty, staff and hundreds of
thousands of Penn State alumni and friends.

1504.text:
Our difficulties are not over,
but I assure you that Penn
State's best days are still ahead.

1511.text:
Again, thank you for the
opportunity to share these
thoughts with you. Thank you.
